question: Please describe in no more than 200 words the following:
llm_answer:
The NeuriTox assay (UKN4) is an in vitro method designed to detect compound-induced impairments in neurite outgrowth in human dopaminergic neurons derived from LUHMES cells. In this assay, proliferating LUHMES cells are seeded and differentiated using tetracycline, cAMP, and GDNF to form post-mitotic neurons with developing neurites. On day two of differentiation, the cells are replated in 96‑well plates and exposed to test compounds for 24 hours. Following toxicant treatment, the cells are live-stained with calcein-AM and Hoechst H‑33342, and the neurite area is quantified by automated high-content imaging, while viability is assessed in parallel. The assay is optimized to identify both developmental neurotoxicity and selective neurite inhibition, with positive control compounds such as narciclasine ensuring assay performance. Its high-throughput format permits screening of compound libraries, making it valuable for hazard evaluation related to neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases. 
(Source: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf)

The assay is designed to assess hazards that can lead to developmental neurotoxicity. In particular, it has been related to adverse outcomes such as:

• Neurodevelopmental disorders that may affect learning and memory, as seen for example in adverse outcome pathways (AOPs) where chronic antagonism of NMDA receptors (AOP 13) or excitotoxicity through ionotropic glutamate receptor overactivation (AOP 48) impair neuronal network function and learning/memory.

• Parkinsonian motor deficits, as the assay targets dopaminergic neurons and is linked to AOP 3 (inhibition of mitochondrial complex I in nigrostriatal neurons).

• In addition, there is linkage to AOPs related to thyroid hormone disruption (AOP 42, AOP 54, AOP 8, and AOP 134) that could lead to adverse neurodevelopmental outcomes and cognitive deficits.

These links are supported by the description in section 8.1 and the more detailed AOP linkages described in sections 9.2 and 9.3.

The protocol is based on a two‐step differentiation process of LUHMES cells onto pre‐coated surfaces. Initially, proliferating LUHMES cells are maintained in a proliferation medium (containing N2, basic fibroblast growth factor, etc.) and, about 24 hours before differentiation (day –1), they are seeded into pre‐coated T75 flasks. This combination triggers the cells to exit the proliferative state and start extending neurites.

After approximately 2 days (48 hours of differentiation), the cells – which now show neurites roughly as long as their cell bodies – are trypsinized and re-plated onto coated 96‑well plates at a defined density. gtruth_answer: Quantification of neurite outgrowth An automated microplate reading microscope (Array-ScanII HCS Reader, Cellomics, PA) equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA-ER camera (resolution 1024 x 1024; run at 2 x 2 binning) was used for image acquisition. Ten fields per well were imaged. Images were recorded in 2 channels using a 20x objective and excitation/emission wavelengths of 365 ± 50/535 ± 45 to detect H-33342 in channel 1 and 474 ± 40/535 ± 45 to detect calcein in channel 2. In both channels, a fixed exposure time and an intensity histogram-derived threshold were used for object identification. Neurite pixels were identified using the following image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified as objects in channel 1 according to their size, area, shape, and intensity which were predefined on untreated cells using a machine-based learning algorithm, and manual selection of nuclei to be classified as intact. The nuclear outlines were expanded by 3.2 µm in each direction, to define a virtual cell soma area (VCSA) based on the following procedure: The average width of the cytoplasm ring (distance nucleus - cell membrane) of LUHMES cells was experimentally determined to be 2.3 µm. Size irregularities were not always due to growing neurites, as determined by combined F-actin/tubulin beta-III staining. To avoid scoring of false positive neurite areas, the exclusion ring (VCSA) was made bigger than the average cell size. Then, we used two control compounds (U0126 and bisindolylmaleimid I) to vary the expanded outlines from 0.6 to 4 µm. We found 3.2 µm to be optimal both to detect neurite growth over time and to identify reduced neurite growth with high sensitivity. All calcein-positive pixels of the field (beyond a given intensity threshold) were defined as viable cellular structures (VCSs). The threshold was dynamically determined for each field after flat field and background correction and intensity normalization to 512 gray values and was set to 12% of the maximal brightness (channel 63 of 512). The VCS defines the sum of all somata and neurites without their assignment to individual cells. In an automatic calculation, the VCSAs, defined in the H- 33342 channel, were used as filter in the calcein channel and subtracted from the VCS. The remaining pixels (VCS - VCSA) in the calcein channel were defined as neurite area. Quantification of individual viable cells by imaging For a quantitative assessment of viable cells, the same images used to assess neurite area were analysed using another image analysis algorithm: nuclei were identified in channel 1 as objects according to their size, area, shape, and intensity. Nuclei of apoptotic cells with increased fluorescence were excluded. A VCSA was defined around each nucleus by expanding it by 0.3 µm into each direction. Calcein-AM staining, labelling live cells, was detected in channel 2. The algorithm quantified the calcein intensity in the VCSA areas. Cells having an average calcein signal intensity in the VCSAs below a predefined threshold were classified by the program as “not viable”. Valid nuclei with a positive calcein signal in their cognate VCSA were counted as viable cells. A positive calcein signal was based on measurements of the average intensity (normal cells: 1300 ± 115, threshold: < 50) and the total integrated intensity (normal cells: 186,000 ± 23,600, threshold < 1000) of cells.

The assay’s image acquisition and analysis are carried out on a Cellomics Array Scan (VTI HCS Reader) equipped with a Hamamatsu ORCA‐ER camera (1024 × 1024 pixels in 2 × 2 binning) using a 20× objective. Fixed exposure times and predefined excitation/emission wavelengths are applied in two channels: one channel detects Hoechst H‑33342 (excitation: 365 ± 50 nm/emission: 535 ± 45 nm) for nucleus/object identification and the other detects calcein (excitation: 474 ± 40 nm/emission: 535 ± 45 nm) for neurite and viability signals. The intensity values are normalized to 512 gray values after flat-field and background correction, with thresholds dynamically determined—for example, a threshold set to 12% of maximal brightness is used in the calcein channel.

For the imaging endpoints, the analysis algorithm works as follows:

• First, nuclei are identified in channel 1 based on preset criteria (size, area, shape, and intensity) that were calibrated using control (untreated) cells. A machine-learning algorithm, combined with manual selection, ensures that only intact nuclei are classified.

• The nuclear outlines are then expanded by 3.2 µm in every direction to create a virtual cell soma area (VCSA). This expansion exceeds the average cytoplasmic ring (experimentally determined as ~2.3 µm) to avoid false positives from soma signals.

• In the calcein (channel 2) images, all pixels with sufficient intensity (above the dynamically set threshold) are collected as viable cell structures (VCS). The algorithm subtracts the VCSA (nuclear area) from the VCS to define the neurite area—the pixels remaining after subtraction are counted as neurite outgrowth.

• For cell viability, the algorithm reanalyzes the same images: nuclei are again identified in the Hoechst channel (with apoptotic cells excluded). A much smaller expansion (0.3 µm in each direction) is applied to form a VCSA around each nucleus, and the calcein intensity within this region is measured. Cells falling below the predefined average intensity (e.g. <50) or total integrated intensity (<1000) thresholds are classified as nonviable. Only nuclei with a calcein-positive VCSA are counted as viable cells.

Data processing is performed by extracting the raw numerical data (e.g. neurite area, cell counts) from the Array Scan software. These data are then copied into Excel, further processed with KNIME and GraphPad Prism, where a four‑parameter log function is used for nonlinear regression (or a linear fit if necessary) to derive EC50 values and other endpoints. Outlier data (which are typically due to technical issues such as focus failure) are identified by visual inspection.

All of these settings, analytical criteria, processing methods, and normalization procedures—including machine settings, image acquisition details, the specific image analysis algorithm, and subsequent data handling steps—are detailed in the standard operating procedure (SOP). The full procedural description is available in DB‑ALM protocol no. 200 (see section 6.6 and the following link: https://ecvam-dbalm.jrc.ec.europa.eu/methods-and-protocols/protocol/ukn4-assay-to-test-compound-derived-impairment-in-neurite-outgrowth-in-differentiating-human-dopaminergic-neurons-protocol-no.-200/key/p_1602).

3. There is no explicit mention of a filtration step for sterilizing the stock or dilution solutions. The protocol relies on aseptic handling and the compounds are prepared and aliquoted under controlled conditions to maintain sterility.

4. The final addition to the test system takes place on 96‑well plates. Here, LUHMES cells have been re‑plated at 30,000 cells per well in 90 µl of differentiation medium (without cAMP and GDNF). Then, approximately 30 minutes to 2 hours after seeding (when the cells have attached but may still appear round) the compounds are added. Dispensing is performed using a multichannel-multistepper pipette configured with filter tips (6 tips at a time). The pipette is set to take in 40 µl with a medium uptake speed and deliver 10 µl per well at a high output speed. Thus each well receives 10 µl of the compound dilution, resulting in a total volume of 100 µl per well (Source: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf, section 6.1).

 • Temperature: The compound dilutions and the DMSO stock are maintained as recommended (DMSO in a lightproof bottle at room temperature; cells are handled quickly to minimize time at room temperature during seeding and medium changes).
 • Lighting: DMSO is protected from light by using a light‑proof container.
 • Lab ware/instruments: Deepwell plates are used for dilution preparation while 96‑well plates are used for the test system. The dispensing is performed with a multichannel-multistepper pipette equipped with filter tips.
 • Decision rules include ensuring that the final DMSO concentration on cells is 0.1% and that the dilution medium (DMEM/F12 Advanced) contains 1% DMSO during the dilution steps to correctly achieve the intended final concentration.
 • The protocol does not detail any specific tests of solubility in the culture medium or as stocks, but good solubility and homogeneity are implied by the requirement to avoid repeated freeze–thaw cycles and the use of DMSO as a solvent.

In summary, compound stocks are prepared in DMSO (stored under light‐protected conditions), aliquoted for single use, and then diluted in DMEM/F12 Advanced (with a built‑in 1% DMSO background) in a deepwell plate. The final 10 µl of each dilution is added to re‑plated cells in 96‑well plates after cell attachment using a multichannel pipette, yielding a final well volume of 100 µl and a final DMSO concentration of 0.1% (Sources: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf, sections 6.1 and 6.4).

1. Problematic compounds:  
 • Some compounds show low solubility during stock preparation and dilution (stock must be prepared in 100% DMSO and then diluted so that the final DMSO concentration on cells remains 0.1%).

llm_answer:
Raw data from the assay are processed in several defined steps. First, the Array Scan VTI HCS Reader acquires images in two channels (Hoechst for nuclei and calcein for viable cells and neurites). The built-in image analysis software first performs flat‐field and background correction and intensity normalization (to 512 gray values). For the calcein channel, a dynamically determined intensity threshold (set at 12% of the maximal brightness) is applied. Then, using the Hoechst channel, nuclei are identified and a virtual cell soma area (VCSA) is defined (by expanding the nuclear outline by a preset distance) so that calcein-positive pixels outside this area are quantified as neurite area. Simultaneously, nuclei coupled with a positive calcein signal within the VCSA are counted as viable cells. (Source: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf, sections 5.4 “Technical details”)

Next, the processed image-derived data (neurite area and cell counts) from all technical replicates are collated by copy‐pasting them into an Excel worksheet. Further data processing is then carried out using tools such as KNIME and GraphPad Prism. In this step, data from treated samples are normalized relative to untreated controls (for example, solvent [0.1% DMSO] treated wells). This normalization expresses endpoints (e.g. neurite area and viability) as percentages relative to control conditions, with any background signal (for example, from medium controls) having been subtracted during the initial background correction.

For concentration–response analysis, the normalized data are fitted using a least‐squares nonlinear regression—typically by a four-parameter log function. In the case of scenarios where a nonlinear fit is not feasible, a linear fit is applied. The EC50 is determined by solving the fitted curve for 50% of the total scale (and not simply 50% of the min–max range). In addition, ratios (such as those used for Benchmark Concentration [BMC] calculations and points of departure [PoD]) are derived from these normalized datasets. Benchmark concentrations (with their upper and lower confidence intervals, BMCU and BMCL) are calculated using external software (BMCeasy) available online. Additional statistical analyses (e.g. one-way ANOVA with Dunnett’s post-test or two-way ANOVA with Tukey-Kramer post hoc testing) may be applied to compare deviations in neurite outgrowth against viability.

In summary, the complete data processing workflow is as follows:
1. Image acquisition with dual-channel imaging.
2. Image analysis including flat field/background correction, intensity normalization, and object (nuclei and neurite) identification.
3. Extraction and collation of numerical data into Excel.
4. Normalization of treated data to control data (background and medium controls are subtracted during image processing).
5. Nonlinear (or linear, if necessary) curve fitting using GraphPad Prism to generate concentration–response curves and derive EC50 values.
6. Calculation of benchmark concentrations (BMCs) and ratios using specialized software (BMCeasy) and application of appropriate statistical tests.

(Sources: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf, sections 5.4, 7.3, and 7.4)

Below is a summary of the benchmark response statistics and thresholds as described for the NeuriTox assay (UKN4) (Sources: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf):

1. Dichotomized outcomes (two classes: toxic versus non‑toxic)  
 • The screening prediction model defines a toxic response if the neurite area is reduced to ≤80% of the DMSO control while cell viability remains ≥90% of control.  
 • In this binary classification, a compound is considered toxic (a “hit”) when it causes a specific decrease in neurite outgrowth without overt cytotoxicity.  
 • Typical baseline variability for neurite outgrowth is reported as an intra‑experimental coefficient of variation of about 11.7% (SD ≈4.5%), and for viability around 3.8% (SD ≈3.5%).  

2. Pseudo‑dichotomized outcomes (three classes: non‑toxic, borderline, toxic)  
 • Borderline compounds are defined using a ratio derived from benchmark concentration (BMC25) estimates: the ratio of BMC25 for viability to BMC25 for neurite area.  
 • A ratio equal to or exceeding 4 is used to classify a compound as specifically neurotoxic, whereas values near this cutoff are considered “borderline.”  
 • In cases where viability does not reach the BMC25 threshold, the highest tested concentration (HTC) is used for the ratio calculation.  

3. Multi‑class or continuous outcomes  
 • Concentration–response relationships are fitted using a four‐parameter logarithmic model.  
 • For defining thresholds, a 25% effect level (BMC25) is used rather than a 50% effect because in routine experiments a moderate (∼25%) reduction in neurite area is more frequently observed given the test concentration range.  
 • The rationale is twofold: mathematically, the 25% effect is reliably detectable within the inherent variability, and biologically, the positive control (narciclasine) consistently produces neurite area reductions in the range of 40–75% of control while maintaining high viability.  

Rationale and Toxicological Basis for the Threshold  
 • The thresholds are partly based on the observed baseline variation (e.g. ∼12% for neurite outgrowth, ∼4% for viability) and the responses elicited by a known positive control (narciclasine).  
 • The 80% neurite area cutoff ensures that only compounds that cause a pronounced decrease in neurite outgrowth (with minimal impact on viability) are flagged for their potential developmental neurotoxicity.  
 • This approach is supported by both mathematical considerations—where a moderate reduction is statistically robust—and a biological rationale, as the assay was designed to capture neurite impairment as a key event in neurotoxic processes.  

Limitations of the Prediction Model  
 • The assay focuses on neurite outgrowth in dopaminergic neurons and may not capture other neurotoxic mechanisms.  
 • In some experiments, certain compounds do not reach the BMC25 for viability, necessitating use of the highest tested concentration as a surrogate.  
 • Variability issues (e.g. differences in plasticware coatings, compound solubility, or autofluorescence) may affect endpoint sensitivity or data interpretation.  
 • Sensitivity and specificity, while high (with reported sensitivity >90% and specificity around 82.7% in one DNT battery evaluation), are limited by the test’s compound set and the fact that not all neurotoxic endpoints are captured.  

Hit Definition in Screening Mode  
 • In a screening scenario, a “hit” is called when a compound causes neurite area to drop below or equal to 80% of control while viability remains at or above 90% of control. This definition is applied to flag compounds for further, more detailed evaluation using the refined prediction models.

This summary reflects the statistical benchmarks, threshold rationales, and limitations as documented in the NeuriTox assay protocol.

The NeuriTox assay (UKN4) is designed as a component of a developmental neurotoxicity (DNT) testing battery. In its documentation the assay is described as having been integrated into a full DNT battery (see section 8.7 and section 9.3 of NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf). Specifically, its performance was compared – for example, when combined with a set of 27 positive DNT compounds, it achieved a sensitivity of 100% and a specificity of 82.7% (source: section 8.7 and 9.3).

Strengths in a testing battery include:
• It has medium to high throughput with automated high-content imaging.
• It offers a mechanistically and quantitatively robust endpoint by specifically measuring neurite outgrowth in human dopaminergic neurons. This readout is particularly relevant for addressing key events established in adverse outcome pathways such as AOP3 (source: sections 8.7 and 8.3).
• It has been successfully used as a screening and confirmation assay, with positive controls (e.g. narciclasine) demonstrating clear inhibition of neurite outgrowth while maintaining viability, making it good for alert generation and mechanistic follow-up (source: sections 8.1, 8.2, and 5.9).

Comparing to similar tests, such as the UKN5 assay (which addresses neurite outgrowth in peripheral neurons), UKN4 is specific for central nervous system dopaminergic neurons. This specialization is an advantage because it targets a cell type that expresses the dopamine transporter (DAT) and is relevant for conditions like parkinsonian motor deficits (source: section 8.7). However, a limitation is that—as a single-endpoint assay—it does not cover all aspects of neurotoxicity observed in vivo. Thus, while it is highly sensitive to neurite outgrowth perturbations, it may miss effects on other neuronal features or functions.

In terms of its placement in a testing strategy, the documentation suggests that the NeuriTox assay is best used as a first-tier test in a DNT battery. It is sufficiently robust to generate alerts on potential neurotoxicants and to confirm hits. In many cases it can be used as a stand-alone method for initial screening, although complementary assays—targeting other neuronal endpoints such as synaptogenesis, electrophysiological activity, or additional markers of viability—might be necessary to cover the full spectrum of neurotoxicity.

In summary:
• The assay fits into DNT testing batteries as a first-tier screening tool and confirmation assay.
• It is particularly strong in mechanistic assessment of neurite outgrowth impairment in CNS dopaminergic neurons.
• Its potential weaknesses are its focus on a single endpoint and the need for highly technical skills and equipment.
• Therefore, while it can be used as a stand-alone method for alert generation, additional complementary assays might be required to cover gaps in the assessment of overall neurotoxicity.

(Sources: NeuriToxassay(UKN4).pdf, sections 8.7, 9.3, 8.1–8.3)
